sub_topics: Introduction to grouping objects by characteristics (colour, size, shape)
Counting groups of objects (1-5)
learning_outcomes: Distinguish groups of things according to their characteristics.
Use whole numbers in a variety of ways in daily life (counting groups).
teaching_and_learning_activities: Teacher-led discussion on everyday objects and their characteristics.
Practical activity: Learners sort classroom objects (e.g., pencils, erasers) into groups.
Game: 'Find and Group' objects based on a given characteristic.
Counting practice with sorted groups using concrete objects.
assessment: Observation of learners' ability to sort objects correctly.
Oral questions on how objects were grouped and how many are in each group.
resources: Charts showing different groups of objects

topic: Things in Our Immediate Surroundings (Science & Mathematics)
sub_topics: Identifying natural and man-made things in the classroom and school environment
Simple classification of items as natural or man-made
Counting and comparing quantities of natural vs. man-made items (up to 5).
learning_outcomes: Explore physical features of natural and man-made environments.
Distinguish groups of things according to their characteristics.
Use whole numbers in a variety of ways in daily life (comparing quantities).
teaching_and_learning_activities: Guided walk around the school environment to observe and identify things.
Class discussion: Differentiating between natural (trees, stones) and man-made (buildings, desks) items.
Drawing activity: Learners draw natural and man-made objects they observed.
Group activity: Collect natural items (leaves, pebbles) and count them.
assessment: Observation of learners' participation in the walk and discussion.
Review of learners' drawings for correct identification.
Oral questions on examples of natural and man-made things and their counts.
resources: Pictures of natural and man-made objects

sub_topics: Understanding the importance of natural resources (e.g., water, trees)
Practicing simple ways to care for resources: Recovering (cleaning up litter), Reducing (using less), Reusing (finding new uses for old items)
learning_outcomes: Care for natural resources using ways such as recovering, reducing, reusing...
teaching_and_learning_activities: Storytelling or video on caring for the environment.
Class discussion on why we need to protect our environment and resources.
Practical activity: Demonstrating reducing waste (e.g., using both sides of paper), reusing items (e.g., plastic bottles for crafts), recovering (e.g., picking up litter in the schoolyard).
Role-play scenarios on 'reducing', 'reusing', 'recovering'.
assessment: Observation of learners' participation in practical activities.
Oral questions on simple ways to care for the environment.
Check for understanding during role-play.
resources: Pictures of clean vs. polluted environments
Waste materials for demonstration (paper, plastic bottles)

sub_topics: What are plants? (Living things, found in our surroundings)
Identifying common parts of a plant (roots, stem, leaves, flower, fruit)
Observing different types of plants in the school environment (e.g., trees, grass, flowers)
learning_outcomes: Classify Plants and Animals according to their characteristics (focus on plants).
Distinguish groups of things according to their characteristics (different plants).
teaching_and_learning_activities: Outdoor observation: Learners identify and name different plants in the school garden/yard.
Teacher-led discussion on plants as living things and their basic parts.
Practical activity: Drawing and labeling a simple plant based on observation.
Singing songs about plants.
assessment: Observation of learners' ability to identify plants outdoors.
Review of labeled drawings of plants.
Oral questions on plant parts.

sub_topics: What are animals? (Living things, found in our surroundings)
Identifying common animals (domestic, farm, and wild animals in our locality)
Observing simple characteristics of different animals (e.g., how they move, where they live)
learning_outcomes: Classify Plants and Animals according to their characteristics (focus on animals).
Distinguish groups of things according to their characteristics (different animals).
teaching_and_learning_activities: Show pictures/videos of various animals (pets, farm animals, wild animals).
Discussion on animal characteristics (e.g., what they eat, how they move, where they live).
Activity: 'Animal Sounds' game.
Drawing and simple naming of familiar animals.
assessment: Observation of participation in animal sound game.
Review of animal drawings for recognition.
Oral questions on animal characteristics.

sub_topics: Similarities and differences between plants and animals (e.g., both grow, move differently)
Basic needs of living things (food, water, air, light/shelter)
Simple classification of plants and animals based on observable traits.
learning_outcomes: Classify Plants and Animals according to their characteristics.
Distinguish groups of things according to their characteristics (living things).
teaching_and_learning_activities: Teacher-led discussion and chart activity comparing plants and animals (e.g., 'What do they need?').
Discussion on what plants and animals need to live and grow.
Matching game: Pictures of plants/animals with their basic needs or simple characteristics.
Group activity: Create a simple 'living things' collage.
assessment: Observation of participation in discussion and activities.
Oral questions comparing plants and animals.
Review of collage for correct placement of living things.

sub_topics: Identifying major external structures of the human body (e.g., head, trunk, limbs)
Simple functions of external body parts (e.g., eyes for seeing, ears for hearing, legs for walking, hands for holding)
learning_outcomes: Relate external structures of the human body to their functions.
teaching_and_learning_activities: Interactive song and dance activity ('Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes').
Teacher-led discussion using a human body chart or model.
Activity: Learners point to and name their own body parts.
Role-play simple actions and identify which body parts are used.
assessment: Observation of learners correctly pointing to and naming body parts.
Oral questions on the function of simple body parts.
Matching pictures of body parts to their functions.

topic: More on Body Parts and Their Functions (Science)
sub_topics: Identifying additional external body parts (e.g., nose, mouth, fingers, toes)
Further exploring the functions of these body parts and their importance.
Understanding sensory organs and their uses (sight, hearing, smell, taste, touch).
learning_outcomes: Relate external structures of the human body to their functions.
teaching_and_learning_activities: Game: 'Simon Says' using various body parts and actions.
Discussion and demonstration of the five senses using body parts and simple objects.
Drawing activity: Draw a person and label their external body parts.
Pair work: Learners describe functions of specific body parts to each other.
assessment: Observation of learners' ability to follow instructions using body parts.
Review of labeled body drawings.
Oral questions on the five senses and their related body parts.
resources: Objects for sensory exploration (e.g., fragrant flower, soft fabric, bell, safe food item for taste)

sub_topics: Introduction to non-standard units of measurement (e.g., hand spans, foot steps, pencils, string)
Measuring length/height of objects in the classroom and self using non-standard units
Comparing measurements (shorter/longer, taller/shorter, same length).
learning_outcomes: Measure using a variety of units (non-standard units).
teaching_and_learning_activities: Teacher demonstration of measuring using hand spans and foot steps.
Practical activity: Learners measure the length of their desks, books, or the classroom using hand spans and other non-standard units.
Comparing heights of learners using non-standard units.
Discussion on why measurement is useful in daily life.
assessment: Observation of learners performing measurements correctly.
Practical task: Measure a specific object and state the measurement in non-standard units.
Oral questions comparing sizes of measured objects.

sub_topics: Importance of personal cleanliness (washing hands, bathing, brushing teeth, keeping clothes clean)
Demonstrating proper handwashing techniques
Understanding why hygiene is important for health and preventing illness.
learning_outcomes: Practise hygiene.
teaching_and_learning_activities: Discussion on daily hygiene routines and their benefits.
Demonstration and practice of effective handwashing (using soap and water).
Story/song about keeping clean and healthy.
Role-play: Showing what to do before eating, after using the toilet, and after playing.
assessment: Observation of learners demonstrating handwashing.
Oral questions on reasons for staying clean.
Check for understanding during role-play scenarios.

sub_topics: What are water-borne diseases? (Simple explanation of how dirty water can make us sick)
Ways to prevent water-borne diseases: Drinking safe water (boiled, filtered), avoiding unsafe water sources.
Practicing safe water habits at home and school.
learning_outcomes: Practise hygiene to prevent Water borne and foodborne diseases (focus on water-borne).
teaching_and_learning_activities: Discussion on different sources of water and which are safe to drink.
Demonstration of simple water purification methods (e.g., boiling, filtering if feasible and safe).
Story about a child who got sick from unsafe water and how to prevent it.
Drawing activity: Show how to get safe drinking water and avoid unsafe water.
assessment: Observation of participation in discussion.
Oral questions on how to get safe drinking water.
Review of drawings for understanding of safe water practices.
resources: Pictures of different water sources (tap, well, river)
Water, pot for boiling/filter materials (if suitable for demonstration)

sub_topics: What are food-borne diseases? (Simple explanation of how dirty food can make us sick)
Ways to prevent food-borne diseases: Washing fruits/vegetables, cooking food properly, keeping food covered, using clean eating utensils.
Practicing safe food handling habits.
learning_outcomes: Practise hygiene to prevent Water borne and foodborne diseases (focus on food-borne).
teaching_and_learning_activities: Discussion on preparing and eating food safely.
Demonstration of washing fruits/vegetables before eating or cooking.
Role-play: Preparing a 'meal' safely (washing hands, covering food, using clean dishes).
Singing a song about healthy food and clean eating habits.
assessment: Observation of learners during demonstrations and role-play.
Oral questions on how to keep food safe.
Identification of safe vs. unsafe food handling practices from pictures.
resources: Fruits/vegetables for washing demonstration (real or pictorial)

sub_topics: Review of all topics covered in Term 1: Grouping, Surroundings, Plants, Animals, Human Body, Measurement, Personal Hygiene, Water-borne and Food-borne Disease Prevention.
learning_outcomes: Consolidate understanding of all Term 1 concepts in Mathematics and Science.
Demonstrate knowledge and skills acquired through various assessment methods.
teaching_and_learning_activities: Interactive Q&A session covering all key concepts.
Review games and quizzes (e.g., 'What am I?', 'True or False', matching games).
Practical recap activities (e.g., sorting objects, identifying body parts, demonstrating handwashing).
Teacher-led review of challenging concepts and common misconceptions.
assessment: Written assessment (simple drawing, matching, circling correct answers, filling in missing words).
Oral assessment (individual questions to check understanding).
Practical assessment (demonstrating skills like handwashing or grouping objects by criteria).
resources: Consolidated notes and charts from the term
